the Jazz handed Seattle its most lopsided defeat

related.description:
Utah Jazz owner Larry Miller wants it made clear: Karl Malone, a.k.a. The Mailman, will continue to make the
majority of his deliveries at the Delta Center.
related.linkText: Jazz owner says he has no plans to trade Malone
related.title: Miller: Trade talks 'dead in the water'
related.headline: Miller: Trade talks 'dead in the water'

article.headline: Jazz end Sonics' three-game winning streak
article.linkText: Struggling Jazz win seventh straight against Sonics
article.story:
SALT LAKE CITY (AP) -- Don't bury the Jazz yet. Karl Malone, John Stockton, Donyell Marshall and even Greg Ostertag showed that Utah can still be quite formidable. Marshall had 20 points and 10 rebounds, Malone scored 19 and Stockton had 18 as the Jazz handed Seattle its most lopsided defeat this season, beating the SuperSonics 112-88 on Wednesday night. "There was good effort defensively, loose balls we were able to get out in the open court and guys played offensively with confidence," Stockton said. "We made mistakes but played through them, and that's important to us." The victory was Utah's seventh straight in the series and snapped Seattle's three-game winning streak. It also gave the Jazz renewed confidence after they got off to their worst start in 19 years. "We've just got to continue to work and try to cut down on some of the things that have hurt us so much, bad decisions and that sort of thing," coach Jerry Sloan said. The Jazz shot 54 percent and won with great ball movement and an overpowering fast break, proving the 39-year-old Stockton and 38-year Malone can still wear down an opponent by running the floor. "It was a big win for us," Malone said. "We're struggling and it was kind of neat to have a complete ball game. We played from start to finish." Utah outscored Seattle 25-2 on the fast break and 62-28 in the paint. The Sonics looked exhausted one night after playing their best game of the season in a 112-102 victory over Minnesota. "They ran and dunked the ball," said Gary Payton, who scored 18. "We're not stopping the transition. We're not doing anything. They were getting rebounds and we weren't effective trying to stop that." Don't tell Sonics coach Nate McMillan that the Jazz aren't themselves these days. "They whipped us. We got a spanking," McMillan said. "Each time we play these guys, their execution is far above ours ... and the games haven't even been close." Vin Baker led the Sonics with 20 points while Rashard Lewis added 13. Ostertag shot 4-for-4 and had eight points, eight rebounds and six blocks. Rookie Andrei Kirilenko had 15 points, four steals and three blocks for Utah while John Starks scored 11 points. Seattle trailed 63-46 at halftime and never got closer. The Jazz steadily pulled away and extended the lead to 98-72 with 7:12 to play on a sequence that epitomized the game. Lewis was blocked twice inside 5 feet, once by Ostertag and again by Kirilenko, then stayed flat on his back as the Russian rookie capped the break with a dunk at the other end. "Defense is going to be the difference for a lot of games," Marshall said. "We've lost a lot of games by one or two points and that's a one or two possession difference." The Jazz got an inspired effort from Ostertag. The often-criticized center played behind rookie Jarron Collins, but Ostertag twice sprinted downcourt for easy layups. "If we keep playing like that, so be it," Ostertag said. "I'll come off the bench the rest of the year if we can do that." Game notes
Jazz owner Larry Miller said last summer's brief trade talks with Dallas involving Malone are "dead in the water." ... Stockton needs two steals to reach 3,000 over his 18-year career. He is the league's career leader in steals and assists. ... In his third NBA game, Collins made his first start, scoring six points and grabbing six rebounds in 24 minutes. ... One night after scoring a career-high 31, Brent Barry finished with five ... Payton has scored in double figures in 47 straight games.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
